abstract.text: Creates an any-to-any converter that uses a color conversion information object to convert from one image format to another.

content.text: Convert Linear Color Space to sRGB

inlineContent.text: You can use

to convert an image with a linear response curve to sRGB. Many vImage operations provide optimal results when working on images with a linear response curve, this approach is ideal for converting between linear and sRGB.

instance:

structure, without a color space, that specifies the pixel memory requirement, number of channels, and alpha information:

abstract.text: Make large-scale mathematical computations and image calculations, optimized for high performance and low energy consumption.
Converts the pixels in a vImage buffer to another format, using the specified converter.
A description of a conversion from one image format to another.
Creates a vImage converter that converts a Core Graphics-formatted image to a Core Video-formatted image.
Creates a vImage converter that converts a Core Video-formatted image to a Core Graphics-formatted image.
Creates an any-to-any converter that uses a color conversion information object to convert from one image format to another.
Creates a vImage converter that converts from one vImage Core Graphics image format to another.
Creates a vImage converter to convert from one vImage Core Graphics image format to another, using custom ColorSync transform.
The description of a Core Graphics image.
An object that describes how to convert between color spaces for use by other system services.
An object that describes how to convert between color spaces for use by other system services.
The basic type for floating-point scalar values in Core Graphics and related frameworks.
A pointer for accessing data of a specific type.
A pointer for accessing and manipulating data of a specific type.
A type for propagating an unmanaged object reference.

media-3583042.alt: Two photographs of a flower. The image on the left has a linear response curve and is very dark. The image on the right is sRGB and correctly rendered.
